issue.title: Question
issue.body:
<!---
IMPORTANT: Please test with the latest released version before
reporting a bug: https://github.com/classgraph/classgraph/releases

When filing a new bug, please call `ClassGraph#verbose()` before
`ClassGraph#scan()`, and attach the generated verbose log to your
bug report. (You can attach log files by dragging and dropping
onto the GitHub issue editing pane.)

If possible, please create and attach a minimal, self-contained
testcase project that is able to trigger the bug. Bugfixes in the
form of pull requests are also very welcome.

Every attempt is made to be extremely responsive in fixing bugs
in ClassGraph (in contrast to many open source projects!).
However, please make sure you are receiving GitHub notifications
so that you can also respond to clarifying questions if necessary.
(GitHub notifications are disabled by default for some users.)

Thank you!
--->

Hey, I'm really sorry I'm making a issue just to ask a question, but I wanted to ask: is there any way to reduce the jar size when using classgraph in the compiled jar? In the Minecraft Spigot scene, jar size is valued (at least to me) more than most programs, and it adds almost half a mb, which stupidly enough is pretty big, especially considering I'm adding it to my dev kit which already adds a ~500 kb. Again, I'm really sorry, but I didn't see anywhere else to ask.

comment.body:
Hey @KojiV, I noticed the large size recently, and I'm actually shocked ClassGraph is that big, because almost the entire size is contained in bytecode. It started out as a tiny project, and it has just grown over the years! I didn't realize JVM classfiles were so inefficient in size.

There is one part of ClassGraph that will be removed in a future version, which is JSON processing, and that will remove a couple of hundred kb, but it won't be that significant a reduction. I'm also going to split the library into two pieces (one as a fast VFS layer), but that won't reduce your total size.

The best suggestion I can give you is that you could try build-time scanning:

https://github.com/classgraph/classgraph/wiki/Build-Time-Scanning

You may also be able to reduce code size by compiling your whole app with GraalVM, since it uses partial evaluation to collapse code down into the smallest possible form -- but I have never tried compiling ClassGraph with Graal, and it's possible it wouldn't work. Let me know if you do get this working though!

issue.title: scan can't find my classes in Adobe AEM project

comment.body:
Hi @jchambers-crescendo, I don't know anything about AEM, but it is very possible that AEM defines its own classloader that ClassGraph doesn't know anything about yet. Are you able to attach the verbose logs, please, along with information about the paths you actually want to scan?

The first thing to check is whether any classloader is detected that ClassGraph was not able to extract classpath entries from. And you need to check whether ClassGraph scanned the paths that you wanted it to scan.

issue.title: Java 9 support and jrt: URLs
issue.body: I was recently trying to research the effects Java 9 will have on class and resource loading and specifically on libraries like Reflections. Based on the info I got (mostly from Mark Reinhold himself), scanning for classes is still possible and Reflections should still work but he noted that, for completeness, it should also scan jrt: URLs. I won't pretend to understand fully what that entails, but was hoping to start a conversation on Java 9 support in Reflections.

issue.title: Language feature: disallow state-changing effects after an external call by default

labels.name: language design :rage4:
labels.description: Any changes to the language, e.g. new features

labels.name: medium effort
labels.description: Default level of effort

labels.name: high impact
labels.description: Changes are very prominent and affect users or the project in a major way.

labels.name: needs design
labels.description: The proposal is too vague to be implemented right away

issue.body:
## Abstract

Generally disallowing state-changing effects after an `external` function call and enabling the possibility to mark functions that specifically do this.

## Motivation

I started this discussion on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/pcaversaccio/status/1523231260721975296) after another reentrancy attack (Cc: @chriseth). Reentrancy attacks are ubiquitous and even though there are toolings available (e.g. Slither) that conduct a static analysis it requires an initial setup as well as a proper understanding of how to interpret the results. In order to make the Solidity development more secure and sustainable I feel it's time to finally introduce such a language feature that disallows state-changing effects after an `external` function call and mark functions that specifically do this.

## Specification

All state-changing effects after an `external` function call are disallowed. If you want to allow however such a possibility, we introduce a new modifier `unprotected` whose default value is `false`.

## Backwards Compatibility

The code that previously compiled fine will not compile anymore if there is a state-change effect after an `external` call and the new modifier `unprotected` is unknown, so it's a breaking change.

comment.body:
> A read-only reentrancy reenters `view` functions which, in contrast to state-altering functions, lack reentrancy guards — enabling the read-only reentrancy. While the reentered contract cannot be affected by its `view` function, others reading the contract's state can. I'm not yet sure how much of such an attack can be prevented at the compiler level since disallowing reentering `view` functions by default is not an appropriate solution IMHO. Any opinions?

Core to this problem is the issue that contract storage reads and writes can be interleaved across inter-contract calls. It seems to me that there would be two ways to prevent this issue, both of which would require EVM changes:

(1) Deny read access to the storage of a contract after the first attempt to write to the contract's storage, until the end of the transaction. This could be switched on with a pragma, for extra security, but it would probably feel restrictive.

(2) Add opcodes to the EVM to read the *consensus-committed* values from storage (i.e. use copy-on-write to keep a copy of the "old" values and the "new" values of the storage of a contract, and have opcodes that only read "old" values. Then, when a transaction is committed, the "new" values are treated as the "old" values for the next transaction). This would require changes to EVM-targeting languages, but it would be possible to treat view functions as quasi-pure, because their return value cannot be affected by any write operation, at least until the transaction is committed.

issue.title: Explained Checks-Effects-Interactions and added info on Checks-Effects-Events-Interactions

comment.body:
OK, I understand your point better now. Thanks for the feedback.

My main reasons for creating this PR is that the current wording is a bit too weak -- users need to know what a huge source of potential vulnerabilities it is to call external contracts before finalizing state -- and also to point out that events should also only be emitted after finalizing state, because otherwise it is possible to trick 3rd parties into believing false things about the final state of the contract after the transaction. (This latter point is raised almost nowhere.)

I'm happy for my suggestion to be completely rewritten, taking these points into account. Unfortunately I don't have bandwidth for this, I was just trying to be helpful by submitting a ready-made change.

issue.title: Explained Checks-Effects-Interactions and added info on Checks-Effects-Events-Interactions

comment.body: @leonardoalt it's a dangerous precedent though to say to your users "you can use this, but you have to be smarter than your potential attackers at reasoning your way through a complex set of logic that proves than any state they can manipulate in the middle of a transaction will ultimately have no negative effect on any user". Far better to make a blanket statement that calling any contract before state is finalized is extremely likely to open you to security vulnerabilities, which it is, and that these security vulnerabilities have lost hundreds of millions of dollars for victims, which they have.

issue.title: Response cache needs to be invalidated when `chainId` changes
issue.body:
If I use MetaMask through WalletConnect, then when I change the network in the wallet, the `chainId` is correctly updated in the provider, as is the RPC URL, but `eth-json-rpc-middleware` continues to return values from the old `chainId`, e.g. the result of `getCode` still refers to code deployed on the old network, not the new one that was just switched to.

`eth_getCode` is marked for caching as `perma`:

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/utils/cache.ts#L81

The cache does not check whether `chainId` has changed when evaluating whether the cache should be used.

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts

The cache needs to be invalidated when `chainId` changes, otherwise stale values will be returned.

comment.body:
Actually the cause may be something different: The cache is invalidated before the block number returned by `await blockTracker.getLatestBlock()`:

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L188

However when the `chainId` changes, the block number changes too. You can see the problem in this screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/811305/184472383-ce351d7a-28cf-472c-b494-be56d5d52cd6.png)

`latestBlockNumber == 0xe9f22b == 15331883` (which is the block number on Mainnet). This is the same number used as a key in `blockCache.cache`: `blockCache.cache[15331883]`.

However, `blockCache.cache[15331883].eth_blockNumber == 0x70d90b == 7395595` (which is the block number on Goerli).

So the Goerli block number (the response to `eth_blockNumber`) has been cached under the Mainnet block number.

When `blockCache.clearBefore(latestBlockNumber)` is given the latest block number from the wrong chain, the cache invalidation does not work as intended, depending on whether the chain switched to has a higher or a lower block number than the chain switched from.

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L190

Really all caches should simply be invalidated when `chainId` changes.

issue.title: WalletConnect Ethereum provider does not work with chainId change

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
I filed a bug report here, but I'm cross-posting to walletconnect-monorepo since I think this may be an issue with the underlying `WalletConnectProvider`, and not with Web3Modal:

https://github.com/WalletConnect/web3modal/issues/552

The issue is that when the `chainId` changes, the provider continues to send API requests to the old `chainId`, which gives the wrong response.

**SDK Version (if relevant)**
 - Client: JS
 - Version: latest

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
See above-linked bug report

**Expected behavior**
WalletConnectProvider should handle `chainId` changes, but it does not. The actual `chainId` updates in the provider, but transactions are still routed to the old chain.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Linux  (connected to MetaMask on Android, accessed via WalletConnect)
 - Browser: Chrome

issue.title: Web3Modal should re-instantiate underlying provider on network change
issue.body:
Web3Modal really needs a call like `web3Modal.update()` that returns a new provider instance if the `chainId` has changed since the call to `web3Modal.connect()`. Currently there is no way to create a new provider instance for the selected provider, and if the `chainId` changes, at least `WalletConnectProvider` does not seem to work with the new `chainId`.

I have the following code:

```javascript
const web3Modal = new Web3Modal({ providerOptions });
const web3ModalProvider = await web3Modal.connect();
web3ModalProvider.on("chainChanged", (chainId) => {
    let provider = new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider);
    console.log("chainId:", (await provider.getNetwork()).chainId);
    console.log("getCode:", (await provider.getCode(contractAddr)).length);
    console.log("eth_getCode:", (await provider.provider.request({
            method: "eth_getCode",
            params: [
                contractAddr.toLowerCase(),
                ethers.utils.hexlify(ethers.BigNumber.from(await provider.getBlockNumber()))
            ]})).length);
});
```

The call to `web3Modal.connect()` returns the injected MetaMask provider, if MetaMask is sellected in the modal popup, or `WalletConnectProvider`, if WalletConnect is selected. This provider is wrapped with a `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider` on each chain change. The underlying provider is available at `provider.provider`.

The above code works correctly for the MetaMask injected provider. If I have a contract deployed at `contractAddr` declared only on `goerli` but no other network, and I switch from `goerli` to `mainnet`, the result shows:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

This shows the contract is declared on `goerli` but not `mainnet`, which is correct.

However if instead I choose to connect to MetaMask using WalletConnect, so that `web3ModalProvider` is a `WalletConnectProvider`, then, the above code instead shows the following when switching from `goerli` to `mainnet`:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301
```

As you can see, `chainId` changes from 5 to 1, but `getCode` and `eth_getCode` are still operating on `goerli` after the network is switched to `mainnet`.

If I instead restart the dapp with the wallet set to `mainnet`, and then I switch from `mainnet` to `goerli`, the result is:

```
chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2

chainId: 5
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

In other words, with the `WalletConnectProvider`, Ethers is somehow getting stuck submitting the `eth_getCode` transaction to the wrong network, even when the `chainId` has changed and the Ethers provider has been recreated using `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider)`. Ethers gets stuck on whatever the first network was that WalletConnect connected to. But this is really weird, because the value of `(await provider.getNetwork()).chainId` is correctly updated by the above code (so Ethers has the correct chainId, and it shouldn't be submitting the transaction to the wrong network).

If a `web3Modal.update()` method is added to Web3Modal, then the `chainChanged` handler could call this method to trigger the creation of a new provider for the selected wallet connection method. (I suspect that `WalletConnectProvider` is not the only provider to suffer from this problem.)

comment.body: I watched network traffic, and when the wrong results are being returned, the problem seems to be that RPC call results are being cached, even though the `chainId` (and therefore the `rpcUrl`) has changed. How do I force the cache to be invalidated?

issue.title: Stacktraces do not show the js source location on Solidity revert

labels.name: not-stale
labels.description: Do not mark this issue as Stale

issue.body:

issue.title: Question
issue.body:
<!---
IMPORTANT: Please test with the latest released version before
reporting a bug: https://github.com/classgraph/classgraph/releases

When filing a new bug, please call `ClassGraph#verbose()` before
`ClassGraph#scan()`, and attach the generated verbose log to your
bug report. (You can attach log files by dragging and dropping
onto the GitHub issue editing pane.)

If possible, please create and attach a minimal, self-contained
testcase project that is able to trigger the bug. Bugfixes in the
form of pull requests are also very welcome.

Every attempt is made to be extremely responsive in fixing bugs
in ClassGraph (in contrast to many open source projects!).
However, please make sure you are receiving GitHub notifications
so that you can also respond to clarifying questions if necessary.
(GitHub notifications are disabled by default for some users.)

Thank you!
--->

Hey, I'm really sorry I'm making a issue just to ask a question, but I wanted to ask: is there any way to reduce the jar size when using classgraph in the compiled jar? In the Minecraft Spigot scene, jar size is valued (at least to me) more than most programs, and it adds almost half a mb, which stupidly enough is pretty big, especially considering I'm adding it to my dev kit which already adds a ~500 kb. Again, I'm really sorry, but I didn't see anywhere else to ask.

comment.body:
Hey @KojiV, I noticed the large size recently, and I'm actually shocked ClassGraph is that big, because almost the entire size is contained in bytecode. It started out as a tiny project, and it has just grown over the years! I didn't realize JVM classfiles were so inefficient in size.

There is one part of ClassGraph that will be removed in a future version, which is JSON processing, and that will remove a couple of hundred kb, but it won't be that significant a reduction. I'm also going to split the library into two pieces (one as a fast VFS layer), but that won't reduce your total size.

The best suggestion I can give you is that you could try build-time scanning:

https://github.com/classgraph/classgraph/wiki/Build-Time-Scanning

You may also be able to reduce code size by compiling your whole app with GraalVM, since it uses partial evaluation to collapse code down into the smallest possible form -- but I have never tried compiling ClassGraph with Graal, and it's possible it wouldn't work. Let me know if you do get this working though!

The first thing to check is whether any classloader is detected that ClassGraph was not able to extract classpath entries from. And you need to check whether ClassGraph scanned the paths that you wanted it to scan.

issue.title: Language feature: disallow state-changing effects after an external call by default

labels.name: language design :rage4:
labels.description: Any changes to the language, e.g. new features

labels.name: medium effort
labels.description: Default level of effort

labels.name: high impact
labels.description: Changes are very prominent and affect users or the project in a major way.

labels.name: needs design
labels.description: The proposal is too vague to be implemented right away

issue.body:
## Abstract

Generally disallowing state-changing effects after an `external` function call and enabling the possibility to mark functions that specifically do this.

## Motivation

I started this discussion on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/pcaversaccio/status/1523231260721975296) after another reentrancy attack (Cc: @chriseth). Reentrancy attacks are ubiquitous and even though there are toolings available (e.g. Slither) that conduct a static analysis it requires an initial setup as well as a proper understanding of how to interpret the results. In order to make the Solidity development more secure and sustainable I feel it's time to finally introduce such a language feature that disallows state-changing effects after an `external` function call and mark functions that specifically do this.

## Specification

All state-changing effects after an `external` function call are disallowed. If you want to allow however such a possibility, we introduce a new modifier `unprotected` whose default value is `false`.

## Backwards Compatibility

The code that previously compiled fine will not compile anymore if there is a state-change effect after an `external` call and the new modifier `unprotected` is unknown, so it's a breaking change.

comment.body:
> A read-only reentrancy reenters `view` functions which, in contrast to state-altering functions, lack reentrancy guards — enabling the read-only reentrancy. While the reentered contract cannot be affected by its `view` function, others reading the contract's state can. I'm not yet sure how much of such an attack can be prevented at the compiler level since disallowing reentering `view` functions by default is not an appropriate solution IMHO. Any opinions?

Core to this problem is the issue that contract storage reads and writes can be interleaved across inter-contract calls. It seems to me that there would be two ways to prevent this issue, both of which would require EVM changes:

(1) Deny read access to the storage of a contract after the first attempt to write to the contract's storage, until the end of the transaction. This could be switched on with a pragma, for extra security, but it would probably feel restrictive.

(2) Add opcodes to the EVM to read the *consensus-committed* values from storage (i.e. use copy-on-write to keep a copy of the "old" values and the "new" values of the storage of a contract, and have opcodes that only read "old" values. Then, when a transaction is committed, the "new" values are treated as the "old" values for the next transaction). This would require changes to EVM-targeting languages, but it would be possible to treat view functions as quasi-pure, because their return value cannot be affected by any write operation, at least until the transaction is committed.

issue.title: Explained Checks-Effects-Interactions and added info on Checks-Effects-Events-Interactions

comment.body:
OK, I understand your point better now. Thanks for the feedback.

My main reasons for creating this PR is that the current wording is a bit too weak -- users need to know what a huge source of potential vulnerabilities it is to call external contracts before finalizing state -- and also to point out that events should also only be emitted after finalizing state, because otherwise it is possible to trick 3rd parties into believing false things about the final state of the contract after the transaction. (This latter point is raised almost nowhere.)

I'm happy for my suggestion to be completely rewritten, taking these points into account. Unfortunately I don't have bandwidth for this, I was just trying to be helpful by submitting a ready-made change.

issue.title: Explained Checks-Effects-Interactions and added info on Checks-Effects-Events-Interactions

comment.body: @leonardoalt it's a dangerous precedent though to say to your users "you can use this, but you have to be smarter than your potential attackers at reasoning your way through a complex set of logic that proves than any state they can manipulate in the middle of a transaction will ultimately have no negative effect on any user". Far better to make a blanket statement that calling any contract before state is finalized is extremely likely to open you to security vulnerabilities, which it is, and that these security vulnerabilities have lost hundreds of millions of dollars for victims, which they have.

issue.title: Response cache needs to be invalidated when `chainId` changes
issue.body:
If I use MetaMask through WalletConnect, then when I change the network in the wallet, the `chainId` is correctly updated in the provider, as is the RPC URL, but `eth-json-rpc-middleware` continues to return values from the old `chainId`, e.g. the result of `getCode` still refers to code deployed on the old network, not the new one that was just switched to.

`eth_getCode` is marked for caching as `perma`:

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/utils/cache.ts#L81

The cache does not check whether `chainId` has changed when evaluating whether the cache should be used.

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts

The cache needs to be invalidated when `chainId` changes, otherwise stale values will be returned.

comment.body:
Actually the cause may be something different: The cache is invalidated before the block number returned by `await blockTracker.getLatestBlock()`:

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L188

However when the `chainId` changes, the block number changes too. You can see the problem in this screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/811305/184472383-ce351d7a-28cf-472c-b494-be56d5d52cd6.png)

`latestBlockNumber == 0xe9f22b == 15331883` (which is the block number on Mainnet). This is the same number used as a key in `blockCache.cache`: `blockCache.cache[15331883]`.

However, `blockCache.cache[15331883].eth_blockNumber == 0x70d90b == 7395595` (which is the block number on Goerli).

So the Goerli block number (the response to `eth_blockNumber`) has been cached under the Mainnet block number.

When `blockCache.clearBefore(latestBlockNumber)` is given the latest block number from the wrong chain, the cache invalidation does not work as intended, depending on whether the chain switched to has a higher or a lower block number than the chain switched from.

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L190

Really all caches should simply be invalidated when `chainId` changes.

 - OS: Linux  (connected to MetaMask on Android, accessed via WalletConnect)
 - Browser: Chrome

issue.title: Web3Modal should re-instantiate underlying provider on network change
issue.body:
Web3Modal really needs a call like `web3Modal.update()` that returns a new provider instance if the `chainId` has changed since the call to `web3Modal.connect()`. Currently there is no way to create a new provider instance for the selected provider, and if the `chainId` changes, at least `WalletConnectProvider` does not seem to work with the new `chainId`.

I have the following code:

```javascript
const web3Modal = new Web3Modal({ providerOptions });
const web3ModalProvider = await web3Modal.connect();
web3ModalProvider.on("chainChanged", (chainId) => {
    let provider = new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider);
    console.log("chainId:", (await provider.getNetwork()).chainId);
    console.log("getCode:", (await provider.getCode(contractAddr)).length);
    console.log("eth_getCode:", (await provider.provider.request({
            method: "eth_getCode",
            params: [
                contractAddr.toLowerCase(),
                ethers.utils.hexlify(ethers.BigNumber.from(await provider.getBlockNumber()))
            ]})).length);
});
```

The call to `web3Modal.connect()` returns the injected MetaMask provider, if MetaMask is sellected in the modal popup, or `WalletConnectProvider`, if WalletConnect is selected. This provider is wrapped with a `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider` on each chain change. The underlying provider is available at `provider.provider`.

The above code works correctly for the MetaMask injected provider. If I have a contract deployed at `contractAddr` declared only on `goerli` but no other network, and I switch from `goerli` to `mainnet`, the result shows:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

This shows the contract is declared on `goerli` but not `mainnet`, which is correct.

However if instead I choose to connect to MetaMask using WalletConnect, so that `web3ModalProvider` is a `WalletConnectProvider`, then, the above code instead shows the following when switching from `goerli` to `mainnet`:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301
```

As you can see, `chainId` changes from 5 to 1, but `getCode` and `eth_getCode` are still operating on `goerli` after the network is switched to `mainnet`.

If I instead restart the dapp with the wallet set to `mainnet`, and then I switch from `mainnet` to `goerli`, the result is:

```
chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2

chainId: 5
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

In other words, with the `WalletConnectProvider`, Ethers is somehow getting stuck submitting the `eth_getCode` transaction to the wrong network, even when the `chainId` has changed and the Ethers provider has been recreated using `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider)`. Ethers gets stuck on whatever the first network was that WalletConnect connected to. But this is really weird, because the value of `(await provider.getNetwork()).chainId` is correctly updated by the above code (so Ethers has the correct chainId, and it shouldn't be submitting the transaction to the wrong network).

If a `web3Modal.update()` method is added to Web3Modal, then the `chainChanged` handler could call this method to trigger the creation of a new provider for the selected wallet connection method. (I suspect that `WalletConnectProvider` is not the only provider to suffer from this problem.)

As you can see, `chainId` changes from 5 to 1, but `getCode` and `eth_getCode` are still operating on `goerli` after the network is switched to `mainnet`.

If I instead restart the dapp with the wallet set to `mainnet`, and then I switch from `mainnet` to `goerli`, the result is:

```
chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2

chainId: 5
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

In other words, with the `WalletConnectProvider`, Ethers is somehow getting stuck submitting the `eth_getCode` transaction to the wrong network, even when the `chainId` has changed and the Ethers provider has been recreated using `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider)`. Ethers gets stuck on whatever the first network was that WalletConnect connected to. But this is really weird, because the value of `(await provider.getNetwork()).chainId` is correctly updated by the above code (so Ethers has the correct chainId, and it shouldn't be submitting the transaction to the wrong network).

If a `web3Modal.update()` method is added to Web3Modal, then the `chainChanged` handler could call this method to trigger the creation of a new provider for the selected wallet connection method. (I suspect that `WalletConnectProvider` is not the only provider to suffer from this problem.)

testcase project that is able to trigger the bug. Bugfixes in the
form of pull requests are also very welcome.

Hey, I'm really sorry I'm making a issue just to ask a question, but I wanted to ask: is there any way to reduce the jar size when using classgraph in the compiled jar? In the Minecraft Spigot scene, jar size is valued (at least to me) more than most programs, and it adds almost half a mb, which stupidly enough is pretty big, especially considering I'm adding it to my dev kit which already adds a ~500 kb. Again, I'm really sorry, but I didn't see anywhere else to ask.

comment.body:
Hey @KojiV, I noticed the large size recently, and I'm actually shocked ClassGraph is that big, because almost the entire size is contained in bytecode. It started out as a tiny project, and it has just grown over the years! I didn't realize JVM classfiles were so inefficient in size.

There is one part of ClassGraph that will be removed in a future version, which is JSON processing, and that will remove a couple of hundred kb, but it won't be that significant a reduction. I'm also going to split the library into two pieces (one as a fast VFS layer), but that won't reduce your total size.

The best suggestion I can give you is that you could try build-time scanning:

https://github.com/classgraph/classgraph/wiki/Build-Time-Scanning

You may also be able to reduce code size by compiling your whole app with GraalVM, since it uses partial evaluation to collapse code down into the smallest possible form -- but I have never tried compiling ClassGraph with Graal, and it's possible it wouldn't work. Let me know if you do get this working though!

issue.title: Language feature: disallow state-changing effects after an external call by default

labels.name: language design :rage4:
labels.description: Any changes to the language, e.g. new features

labels.name: medium effort
labels.description: Default level of effort

labels.name: high impact
labels.description: Changes are very prominent and affect users or the project in a major way.

labels.name: needs design
labels.description: The proposal is too vague to be implemented right away

issue.body:
## Abstract

Generally disallowing state-changing effects after an `external` function call and enabling the possibility to mark functions that specifically do this.

## Motivation

I started this discussion on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/pcaversaccio/status/1523231260721975296) after another reentrancy attack (Cc: @chriseth). Reentrancy attacks are ubiquitous and even though there are toolings available (e.g. Slither) that conduct a static analysis it requires an initial setup as well as a proper understanding of how to interpret the results. In order to make the Solidity development more secure and sustainable I feel it's time to finally introduce such a language feature that disallows state-changing effects after an `external` function call and mark functions that specifically do this.

## Specification

All state-changing effects after an `external` function call are disallowed. If you want to allow however such a possibility, we introduce a new modifier `unprotected` whose default value is `false`.

## Backwards Compatibility

The code that previously compiled fine will not compile anymore if there is a state-change effect after an `external` call and the new modifier `unprotected` is unknown, so it's a breaking change.

comment.body:
> A read-only reentrancy reenters `view` functions which, in contrast to state-altering functions, lack reentrancy guards — enabling the read-only reentrancy. While the reentered contract cannot be affected by its `view` function, others reading the contract's state can. I'm not yet sure how much of such an attack can be prevented at the compiler level since disallowing reentering `view` functions by default is not an appropriate solution IMHO. Any opinions?

Core to this problem is the issue that contract storage reads and writes can be interleaved across inter-contract calls. It seems to me that there would be two ways to prevent this issue, both of which would require EVM changes:

(1) Deny read access to the storage of a contract after the first attempt to write to the contract's storage, until the end of the transaction. This could be switched on with a pragma, for extra security, but it would probably feel restrictive.

(2) Add opcodes to the EVM to read the *consensus-committed* values from storage (i.e. use copy-on-write to keep a copy of the "old" values and the "new" values of the storage of a contract, and have opcodes that only read "old" values. Then, when a transaction is committed, the "new" values are treated as the "old" values for the next transaction). This would require changes to EVM-targeting languages, but it would be possible to treat view functions as quasi-pure, because their return value cannot be affected by any write operation, at least until the transaction is committed.

issue.title: Explained Checks-Effects-Interactions and added info on Checks-Effects-Events-Interactions

comment.body:
OK, I understand your point better now. Thanks for the feedback.

My main reasons for creating this PR is that the current wording is a bit too weak -- users need to know what a huge source of potential vulnerabilities it is to call external contracts before finalizing state -- and also to point out that events should also only be emitted after finalizing state, because otherwise it is possible to trick 3rd parties into believing false things about the final state of the contract after the transaction. (This latter point is raised almost nowhere.)

I'm happy for my suggestion to be completely rewritten, taking these points into account. Unfortunately I don't have bandwidth for this, I was just trying to be helpful by submitting a ready-made change.

issue.title: Explained Checks-Effects-Interactions and added info on Checks-Effects-Events-Interactions

comment.body: @leonardoalt it's a dangerous precedent though to say to your users "you can use this, but you have to be smarter than your potential attackers at reasoning your way through a complex set of logic that proves than any state they can manipulate in the middle of a transaction will ultimately have no negative effect on any user". Far better to make a blanket statement that calling any contract before state is finalized is extremely likely to open you to security vulnerabilities, which it is, and that these security vulnerabilities have lost hundreds of millions of dollars for victims, which they have.

issue.title: Response cache needs to be invalidated when `chainId` changes
issue.body:
If I use MetaMask through WalletConnect, then when I change the network in the wallet, the `chainId` is correctly updated in the provider, as is the RPC URL, but `eth-json-rpc-middleware` continues to return values from the old `chainId`, e.g. the result of `getCode` still refers to code deployed on the old network, not the new one that was just switched to.

`eth_getCode` is marked for caching as `perma`:

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/utils/cache.ts#L81

The cache does not check whether `chainId` has changed when evaluating whether the cache should be used.

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts

The cache needs to be invalidated when `chainId` changes, otherwise stale values will be returned.

comment.body:
Actually the cause may be something different: The cache is invalidated before the block number returned by `await blockTracker.getLatestBlock()`:

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L188

However when the `chainId` changes, the block number changes too. You can see the problem in this screenshot:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/811305/184472383-ce351d7a-28cf-472c-b494-be56d5d52cd6.png)

`latestBlockNumber == 0xe9f22b == 15331883` (which is the block number on Mainnet). This is the same number used as a key in `blockCache.cache`: `blockCache.cache[15331883]`.

However, `blockCache.cache[15331883].eth_blockNumber == 0x70d90b == 7395595` (which is the block number on Goerli).

So the Goerli block number (the response to `eth_blockNumber`) has been cached under the Mainnet block number.

When `blockCache.clearBefore(latestBlockNumber)` is given the latest block number from the wrong chain, the cache invalidation does not work as intended, depending on whether the chain switched to has a higher or a lower block number than the chain switched from.

https://github.com/MetaMask/eth-json-rpc-middleware/blob/main/src/block-cache.ts#L190

Really all caches should simply be invalidated when `chainId` changes.

issue.title: Web3Modal should re-instantiate underlying provider on network change
issue.body:
Web3Modal really needs a call like `web3Modal.update()` that returns a new provider instance if the `chainId` has changed since the call to `web3Modal.connect()`. Currently there is no way to create a new provider instance for the selected provider, and if the `chainId` changes, at least `WalletConnectProvider` does not seem to work with the new `chainId`.

I have the following code:

```javascript
const web3Modal = new Web3Modal({ providerOptions });
const web3ModalProvider = await web3Modal.connect();
web3ModalProvider.on("chainChanged", (chainId) => {
    let provider = new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider);
    console.log("chainId:", (await provider.getNetwork()).chainId);
    console.log("getCode:", (await provider.getCode(contractAddr)).length);
    console.log("eth_getCode:", (await provider.provider.request({
            method: "eth_getCode",
            params: [
                contractAddr.toLowerCase(),
                ethers.utils.hexlify(ethers.BigNumber.from(await provider.getBlockNumber()))
            ]})).length);
});
```

The call to `web3Modal.connect()` returns the injected MetaMask provider, if MetaMask is sellected in the modal popup, or `WalletConnectProvider`, if WalletConnect is selected. This provider is wrapped with a `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider` on each chain change. The underlying provider is available at `provider.provider`.

The above code works correctly for the MetaMask injected provider. If I have a contract deployed at `contractAddr` declared only on `goerli` but no other network, and I switch from `goerli` to `mainnet`, the result shows:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

This shows the contract is declared on `goerli` but not `mainnet`, which is correct.

However if instead I choose to connect to MetaMask using WalletConnect, so that `web3ModalProvider` is a `WalletConnectProvider`, then, the above code instead shows the following when switching from `goerli` to `mainnet`:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301
```

As you can see, `chainId` changes from 5 to 1, but `getCode` and `eth_getCode` are still operating on `goerli` after the network is switched to `mainnet`.

If I instead restart the dapp with the wallet set to `mainnet`, and then I switch from `mainnet` to `goerli`, the result is:

```
chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2

chainId: 5
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

In other words, with the `WalletConnectProvider`, Ethers is somehow getting stuck submitting the `eth_getCode` transaction to the wrong network, even when the `chainId` has changed and the Ethers provider has been recreated using `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider)`. Ethers gets stuck on whatever the first network was that WalletConnect connected to. But this is really weird, because the value of `(await provider.getNetwork()).chainId` is correctly updated by the above code (so Ethers has the correct chainId, and it shouldn't be submitting the transaction to the wrong network).

If a `web3Modal.update()` method is added to Web3Modal, then the `chainChanged` handler could call this method to trigger the creation of a new provider for the selected wallet connection method. (I suspect that `WalletConnectProvider` is not the only provider to suffer from this problem.)

    let provider = new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider);
    console.log("chainId:", (await provider.getNetwork()).chainId);
    console.log("getCode:", (await provider.getCode(contractAddr)).length);
    console.log("eth_getCode:", (await provider.provider.request({
            method: "eth_getCode",
            params: [
                contractAddr.toLowerCase(),
                ethers.utils.hexlify(ethers.BigNumber.from(await provider.getBlockNumber()))
            ]})).length);
});
```

The call to `web3Modal.connect()` return the injected MetaMask provider, if MetaMask is sellected in the modal popup, or `WalletConnectProvider`, if WalletConnect is selected.

The above code works correctly for the MetaMask injected provider. If I have a contract deployed at `contractAddr` declared only on `goerli` but no other network, and I switch from `goerli` to `mainnet`, the result shows:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

This shows the contract is declared on `goerli` but not `mainnet`, which is correct.

However if instead I choose to connect to MetaMask using WalletConnect, so that `web3ModalProvider` is a `WalletConnectProvider`, then, the above code instead shows the following when switching from `goerli` to `mainnet`:

```
chainId: 5
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301

chainId: 1
getCode: 26301
eth_getCode: 26301
```

As you can see, `chainId` changes from 5 to 1, but `getCode` and `eth_getCode` are still operating on `goerli` after the network is switched to `mainnet`.

If I instead restart the dapp with the wallet set to `mainnet`, and then I switch from `mainnet` to `goerli`, the result is:

```
chainId: 1
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2

chainId: 5
getCode: 2
eth_getCode: 2
```

In other words, with the `WalletConnectProvider`, Ethers is somehow getting stuck submitting the `eth_getCode` transaction to the wrong network, even when the `chainId` has changed and the Ethers provider has been recreated using `new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(web3ModalProvider)`. Ethers gets stuck on whatever the first network was that WalletConnect connected to. But this is really weird, because the value of `(await provider.getNetwork()).chainId` is correctly updated by the above code (so Ethers has the correct chainId, and it shouldn't be submitting the transaction to the wrong network).

If a `web3Modal.update()` method is added to Web3Modal, then the `chainChanged` handler could call this method to trigger the creation of a new provider for the selected wallet connection method. (I suspect that `WalletConnectProvider` is not the only provider to suffer from this problem.)

issue.title: Stacktraces do not show the js source location on Solidity revert

labels.name: not-stale
labels.description: Do not mark this issue as Stale

issue.body:
When a transaction is reverted within a contract, the js line containing the contract method call is not shown in the stacktrace. Instead only Hardhat block mining methods are shown:

```
     Error: VM Exception while processing transaction: reverted with reason string 'Some Solidity revert message'
      at MyContract.someMethod (contracts/main/MyContract.sol:100)
      at async HardhatNode._mineBlockWithPendingTxs (node_modules/hardhat/src/internal/hardhat-network/provider/node.ts:1773:23)
      at async HardhatNode.mineBlock (node_modules/hardhat/src/internal/hardhat-network/provider/node.ts:466:16)
      at async EthModule._sendTransactionAndReturnHash (node_modules/hardhat/src/internal/hardhat-network/provider/modules/eth.ts:1504:18)
      at async HardhatNetworkProvider.request (node_modules/hardhat/src/internal/hardhat-network/provider/provider.ts:118:18)
      at async EthersProviderWrapper.send (node_modules/@nomiclabs/hardhat-ethers/src/internal/ethers-provider-wrapper.ts:13:20)
```

comment.body:
Correct, I'm using Ethers for tests, Hardhat for execution. The first stackrace I showed was a Hardhat stacktrace, the second was an ethers stacktrace, both showing the same problem of not including the js line that made the Solidity method invocation.

Ethers 6 is a major revamp, so maybe the situation will improve?
